Description.3: Lab Report: Two in-person labs will be run , with an online quiz to test understanding
Description.4: Continuous Assessment: 3 Online quizzes: 1) circuit analysis (Approximately week 6, worth 5%), 2) circuit analysis and electromagnetics (Approx week 8, worth 10%), 3) digital electronics (approx week 11, worth 10%)
Description.5: Class Test: A midterm examination of relevant topics in electronic, mechanical and software engineering
Description.6: Assignment: Various design, programming and simulation exercises.
Description.9: Studio Examination: In-studio assessment of group assignments

Description.15: Group Project: How Structures Stand Up

Description.21: Continuous Assessment: Laboratories are guided by Teaching Assistants/Demonstrators. Marks are awarded for these laboratories based on attendance, preparation and exercise completion (where applicable).
Description.24: Group Project: Device design and performance, group project report, video and poster
Description.25: Portfolio: A portfolio containing the full range of work done by the student is submitted at the end of semester
Description.26: Portfolio: A portfolio containing the full range of work done by the student is submitted at the end of the semester, to which a letter grade is allocated by the Studio Staff & ratified by the School & Externs.
Description.30: Portfolio: A portfolio is submitted at the end of the semester. The portfolio will contain all work completed, e.g. technology drawings, models, photographs of completed models, sketches and rough work.
Description.31: Essay: Peer Assessment. The student will be asked to review and give feedback to their Peer's work using peerScholar through Brightspace.
Description.32: Assignment: 3. Choose a reading in Week 6 of this architectural history SURVEY module from a set of core readings; make a summary of that reading in a provided template and upload the summary by 12 Nov 2022
Description.33: Assignment: 4. Academic Integrity Exercise designed by UCD Library /Writing Centre around plagiarism and referencing. This is like a class test but carried out on Brightspace by 26th Nov 2022
Description.34: Assignment: 1. Choose a reading in Week 1 of this architectural history SURVEY module from a set of core readings; make a summary of that reading in a provided template and upload the summary by 8 Oct 2022
Description.35: Examination: 5. End of module exam for which you will prepare 2 longer questions and answer a 3rd question on referencing.
Description.36: Essay: 2. Observation writing: Write a short essay which pays close attention to a chosen site in Dublin. Visit + sketch, observe + photograph the site, write a 500-word observational essay, by 29 Oct 2022
Description.37: Examination: Assignment 4 = Exam. The exam consists of 2 prepared long questions and 1 shorter unseen question.
Description.38: Assignment: Assignment 1 = Reading summaryChoice of architectural writing to be read and summarised by week 2.
Description.39: Assignment: Assignment 3 = media reviewVisit an exhibition or listen to a podcast and write a review for week 10.
Description.40: Assignment: Assignment 2 = Building Research and Writing Exercise. In partnership with Drawing + Making and Studio modules, this is a research and writing exercise which is due in week 7.

Description.44: Group Project: Group Project and presentation on topical environmental issue
Description.45: Continuous Assessment: Assessments linked to workshops
Description.46: Multiple Choice Questionnaire: End-of-term online MCQ
Description.47: Multiple Choice Questionnaire: Mid-term online MCQ
Description.48: Multiple Choice Questionnaire: The multiple choice questionnaire contains questions on all lectures.
Description.49: Assignment: Students produce a concept to provide essential information for the design of an environmental economic policy relying on environmental economic tools.
Description.50: Assignment: Students produce a policy-brief suggesting a solution to an environmental problem of their choice. The policy-brief highlights key concepts from the environmental economics literature.

Description.52: Continuous Assessment: regular presentations/reviews of project work
Description.53: Portfolio: submission of all semester work in a portfolio and contribution to the end-of-term student showcase
Description.54: Continuous Assessment: Regular presentation/review of course work

Description.56: Portfolio: End of term submission of entire body of course work and contribution to end-of-term student showcase

Description.73: Group Project: Group project 1- Development plans

Description.79: Lab Report: Based on two laboratory experiments that all students are expected to complete, while working in pairs, and collaborating with other pairs. Each lab is weighted equally.
Description.80: Examination: An end of trimester online MCQ examination will assess each student's overall understanding of the module. Resit students will be assessed wholly on the basis of this written examination.
Description.81: Group Project: Groups of students (approximately 5 per group) will be required to collaborate on an assignment that is intended to allow students to demonstrate their understanding of key concepts of this module.
Description.82: Class Test: In-class MCQ tests will be set randomly throughout the trimester, without announcement, to provide students with formative feedback on their understanding of course material.
Description.83: Examination: In-person, 2-hour, end of trimester exam
Description.84: Class Test: Online BrightSpace Quiz (50 minutes)
Description.86: Lab Report: Two Reports to be submitted by each student, following participation in a scheduled laboratory practical session.
